awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Designing Hund's Metals from Transition Metal Sulfides
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary
With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, the Principal Investigator's NSF CAREER plan focuses on the development of a new class of materials with functional magnetic and electronic properties.  These crystalline solids are termed Hund's metals and their unique electrical behavior arises from the combination of abundant metals such as iron and copper with sulfur.  Furthermore, the manner in which these elements come together to form crystals is highly important in tailoring their materials properties.  To prepare these new compounds, the PI develops new chemical methods available to the broader, national community of materials scientists.  The project provides training for both graduate and undergraduate students in the synthesis of new solids and in characterizing their atomic structure and physical properties with advanced instrumentation.  Part of the students' training also includes participation in outreach activities where they engage high school students in the immediate vicinity of the University of Maryland.  The PI and his group of university students mentor the high school chemistry students, whom are predominately Hispanic, African American and underrepresented in the sciences, through activities that include chemistry tutoring and guided tours of nearby national laboratories.  

Technical Summary
The research group is engaged in hypothesis-driven synthesis of new sulfides defined as Hund's metals.  These materials are composed of late transition metal sulfides and possess the electronic properties characteristic of a metal while expressing localized magnetic behavior through interactions dictated by Hund's rule for maximizing spin.  The uniqueness of these Hund's metals arises from the d-orbital behavior of the d-block elements including iron, cobalt, nickel, and copper.  While one subset of the five d-orbitals form electronic bands that split across the Fermi level, as in an insulator, the others form itinerant bands.  The research projects specifically target sulfides that contain certain crystal structure motifs including either octanuclear clusters or two-dimensional sheets of the d-block elements.  In both cases, the transition metal is always tetrahedrally coordinated to sulfide anions in order to minimize the crystal field splitting and therefore favor a high spin configuration, which leads to the desired magnetic behavior of the Hund's metals.  The research goals include experimentally confirming the predicted phases through solid state synthesis and crystal growth followed by measurements of the new phases' magnetization, electrical transport, and specific heat properties.  Neutron diffraction and inelastic neutron scattering are utilized to measure both the structure and dynamics in these sulfides.  For the two-dimensional layered sulfides, soft chemical methods such as intercalation of lithium in liquid ammonia are pursued in order to form metastable phases, which are prone to display extraordinary electronic behavior such as superconductivity.

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF CAREER researched activities focused on developing a new class of materials called Hund's metals. As their name implies, these materials possess the physical characteristic of a metal combined with magnetic interactions characterized by Hund's rules. These materials fall under the broader category of quantum materials.

Intellectual Merit. We focused much of our research activities on the synthesis and single crystal growth of new inorganic materials. Our laboratory's uniquely qualifications to carry out this research were based on our expertise in superconductors, crystallography, magnetism, and solid state synthesis. We then carried out the following specific tasks.

- Soft chemical methods, or chemie douce, for the synthesis of layered metal chalcogenides. These phases are comprised of infinite sheets of edge-sharing MQ4 tetrahedra where M = Fe, Co, Mn, and Cu and Q= S, Se. The metastability of the target phases precluded conventional solid state synthesis at high temperatures. The advantage of pursuing such chemie douce routes was the ability to kinetically trap target structures at low temperatures.  An example from our work was the preparation for the first time of a tetragonal phase of CoS and CoSe. We manipulated a thermodynamically stable phase in water and at room temperature to convert it to a kinetically-trapped phase. We also followed up this synthetic work with extensive studies on the insertion of different cationic species into these layers, which is known as intercalation chemistry, in order to tune the physical properties.

- Physical and spectroscopic measurements of polycrystalline and single crystal samples. We did not just synthesize new phases and characterize their crystal structures. We also made sure to explore their functional behavior and to isolate the most promising candidates in the field of quantum materials. To characterize our quantum materials, we measured the magnetic susceptibility, magnetization, electrical resistivity, and specific heat properties down to low temperatures of 2.8 K. We produced not only magnetic metals, but also superconductors and magnetic superconductors.

Overall, we published 16 papers through this grant. Out of those 16 publications, two were book chapters including one titled "Hydrothermal Synthesis and Crystal Growth", which will be published in a forthcoming book co-authored by the PI, Fundamentals of Quantum Materials (World Scientific Publishing Company, 2020). We have two more manuscripts planned for publication and one is currently under review.

Our CAREER grant supported four PhD students. The completed PhD theses include: Dr. Xiuquan Zhou "Intercalation Chemistry of Tetrahedral Transition Metal Chalcogenides" (2018); Dr. Austin Virtue "Structure and Properties of Alloyed Chalcogenides with the ThCr2Si2-type Structure" (2019); and Dr. Brandon C. Wilfong "Magnetism and Superconductivity in Topotactically Modified Transition Metal Chalcogenides" (2020). I anticipate one more thesis to come out of this work by my current 4 year graduate student Huafei Zheng.

Broader Impacts. We developed an outreach program to increase the participation of underrepresented students around and within the University of Maryland (UMD) in STEM, with a special emphasis on high school students and undergraduates. We implemented this plan through a chemistry tutoring program, which we initiated at the nearby Northwestern High School. The main mode of implementing these outreach activities was through the establishment of a chemistry club for the undergraduates called the American Chemical Society (ACS) UMD student affiliates. After a couple of years, we switched our tutoring efforts from Northwestern High School (NHS) to College Park Academy (CAP), which is also located in Prince George's County. CPA has similar demographics to NHS's since both have majority Black and Hispanic/Latino students, which were our targeted demographic. The undergraduate students were inspired to continue their tutoring during the duration of this grant. We also raised extra funds through grant applications and crowdfunding to send the ACS student affiliates involved in the tutoring program to the national ACS conferences. There, they presented their tutoring and outreach work.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic we stopped the tutoring program at the very end of the grant's reporting period. Furthermore, I have now stepped down as the adviser of the ACS student affiliates club and have passed the torch to a younger colleague. During this year of the pandemic, I have transitioned my outreach efforts to a more focused activity of using 3D printing to teach structural chemistry to local high schools.

During the duration of this grant, I also took in 4 undergraduate interns from the NSF-sponsored Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) to work in my laboratory. My highly successful LSAMP student Hector Vivanco co-authored 4 papers with me and is currently working on his PhD on the topic of quantum materials at Johns Hopkins University.
